CatDescriptText: Mr. Melvin W. Davis, government accountant, Sheraden and Mr. Calvin Black, postal worker, Homestead, were part of the Pittsburghers Speak Up column published in Pittsburgh Courier newspaper, April 1, 1961, pg. 7 with question: "Do you believe in capital punishment?  If not, what type of punishment do you suggest for those who commit what is generally termed "vicious murder."  Mr. Davis' answer reads: "...Any murder which is pre-meditated, should be punishable by death."  Mr. Black's answer reads: " I certainly do.  There are a lot of people killed today, unnecessarily, and this occurs even with a hammer over the head of the perpetrators.  Take away that hammer-that threat of the death penalty-and a person would be afraid to walk out of the house..."
TitMainTitle: Two frames: Portrait of Melvin W. Davis wearing fedora, dark overcoat, and plaid tie, standing in front of building entrance; Portrait of Calvin Black wearing dark zippered jacket and dark cap with patch reading "U. S. Post Office 107, Special Delivery Messenger"
